moves.1. f4: White opens with the f-pawn. This weakens the king's position, so I never play Bird's opening.
moves.1... d5 2. Nf3 c5: Black has a nice pawn duo in the center.
moves.6. Qxf3 Nc6 7. Bb2 cxd4 8. exd4 Nb4: White's Queenside is weak, so Black attacks there.
moves.9. Bd3 Rc8 10. O-O Nxc2 11. Bxc2 Rxc2 12: Black wins a pawn, and now should retreat the rook, else it gets trapped as in this game.
moves.12... Nf6 13. Nc3 g6 14. Qd3: Now Black must sac the major exchange.
moves.14... Rxc3 15. Qxc3 Bg7: Here, Re1 would be met by ... Ne4.
moves.16. Bc5 O-O 17. Rae1 Ne4 18. Qe3 Re8: Of course not ... Nxc5. The centralized knight is much better than the bishop.
moves.19. f5: White opens the f-file for his heavy artillery.
moves.19... b6 20. Ba3 Qd7: Finally, black's development is complete after 20 moves.
moves.23. Kh1 Bf6: Black's position is quite solid here. White could return the exchange though with Rxe4, but then black's e-pawn becomes dangerous.
moves.24. Qh6 Rc8 25. Rf3: Black should contest the c-file with Rc1 instead of trying to mate on h7, which is impossible because of Ng5 or simply moving the king to f8 after Qh7+.
moves.27. Rg1: Material is even, but Black's attack is too strong.
moves.29. g3 Qh3#: Game Over. This is why you should open with the F-pawn (else you'll get @$$ F***ed).
